Nathan,
 
Radio shack has plenty of 12-469's
run out get yourself one, A g=
uy a smart as you should have no problem hacking it.
 
Just make sure the m=
en in black are not watching  
 
Bruce
Bruce Halliday 


To: EVP-ITC@yahoog=
roups.comFrom: v1230mail@...: Mon, 14 Apr 2008 00:57:54 +0000Subj=
ect: [EVP-ITC] Re:First SuCcessful Recordings - Nathan re: Hoax




I HAVE =
NEVER USED THE BOX, I MADE A REQUEST TO ITCDEADPEOPLE TO SED MEONE.i WANT T=
O EXPERIMENT WITH IT, SOUNDS EXCITING.--- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "itcd=
eadpeople" <ITCdeadpeople@...> wrote:>> Hi Nathan. I always look to relevan=
ce as a key in determiningwhether or not something is > appropriate to the =
session. If this were a hoax, I would then haveto seek an explanation > for=
 how private information is known by the 'hoax perp',particularly informati=
on that > would require visual awareness. > > Some of us have examples of a=
ppropriate responses being given whenasking things like, > "Can you name so=
mething nearby me?" or "Please tell me what I'mholding in my left > hand." =
A sophisticated multi-transmission two way radio would notexplain answers >=
 which require 'visual' information of some kind (though I'll be thefirst t=
o admit my > understanding of electronics is limited but I'm fairly confide=
nt onthis aspect.) > > Of course, there is always the chance that the perso=
n running thehoax is also, or in > partnership with, an extremely talented =
remote viewer or psychic whois able to glean that > visual information from=
 the ether or the mind of the experimenter. > > And what of those examples =
where people have confirmed the sound ofthe voice being > "just like" that =
of their loved one in spirit? Surely the hoaxerisn't also able to mimic > p=
eople's loved ones.> > If you are using EVP Maker with anything other than =
the allophonesfile, which contains no > words to begin with, you are also r=
unning the possibility of 'falsepositives' albeit they > wouldn't be from a=
 hoax. Again, I look to relevance to be key, andrelevant info that > would =
not come easily to a stranger is even better. > > For example, I turned on =
my MiniBox for the very first time andsaid, "Hello?" and > immediately rece=
ived the response, "Hello Margaret." If this were ahoax, how could that > p=
erson know in less than 10 seconds, who I was by name. I had notgiven this =
information > out. Not to mention that you have people experimenting 24/7 a=
ndreceiving similar > responses. How in the world could an organization hav=
e themanpower, technology, or > even the desire, to attempt such a hoax? I =
mean that as a genuineinquiry, because there > might be an explanation I ha=
ve not thought of. > > I have one example where, via radio sweep, my commun=
icator was ableto correctly > identify the status and location of a missing=
 person (who it turnsout was alive and well, so > we ended up with confirma=
tion that the info given had indeed beencorrect - which is > much less comp=
licated that trying to track and understand the clueswhen associated with >=
 the dead, or missing but not found.) Again, if a hoax, would thathave simp=
ly been a > lucky guess on the part of the hoaxer?> > Bottom line for me is=
 ... have I wondered if it could be a hoax? Orsimply a fortuitous > tuning =
of the dial? Yes, on both accounts. But there is enoughcompelling evidence =
to rule > out both of them as an explanation for the far too many relevante=
xamples received by so > many of us.> > Good food for thought, but after di=
gesting it, I'd have to say, "No,a sophisticated hoax > does not sufficient=
ly explain the phenomena on a large scale."> > Margaret> > --- In EVP-ITC@y=
ahoogroups.com, Nathan Sharman <v1230mail@> wrote:> >> > Has it ever occurr=
ed to you, that some one or> > organisation, could be using a radio to say =
the things> > you heard?> > > > This whole radio and spirit voices, could b=
e a MASSIVE> > HOAX, perpetuated by some one with a sophisticated> > multi-=
transmission two way radio.> > > > Think about it.> > > > THAT IS WHY I USE=
 EVPmaker only to commuincate with> > the other dimension.> > > > _________=
_________________________________________> > Do You Yahoo!?> > Tired of spa=
m? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around > > http://mail.yahoo.co=
m> >>

iven when<BR>asking things like, <BR>> "Can you name something nearby me=

isticated multi-transmission two way radio would not<BR>explain answers <BR=

s always the chance that the person running the<BR>hoax is also, or in <BR>=

R>is able to glean that <BR>> visual information from the ether or the m=
ind of the experimenter. <BR>> <BR>> And what of those examples where=
 people have confirmed the sound of<BR>the voice being <BR>> "just like"=
 that of their loved one in spirit? Surely the hoaxer<BR>isn't also able to=
 mimic <BR>> people's loved ones.<BR>> <BR>> If you are using EVP =
Maker with anything other than the allophones<BR>file, which contains no <B=
R>> words to begin with, you are also running the possibility of 'false<=
BR>positives' albeit they <BR>> wouldn't be from a hoax. Again, I look t=
o relevance to be key, and<BR>relevant info that <BR>> would not come ea=
sily to a stranger is even better. <BR>> <BR>> For example, I turned =
on my MiniBox for the very first time and<BR>said, "Hello?" and <BR>> im=
mediately received the response, "Hello Margaret." If this were a<BR>hoax, =
how could that <BR>> person know in less than 10 seconds, who I was by n=
ame. I had not<BR>given this information <BR>> out. Not to mention that =
you have people experimenting 24/7 and<BR>receiving similar <BR>> respon=
ses. How in the world could an organization have the<BR>manpower, technolog=
y, or <BR>> even the desire, to attempt such a hoax? I mean that as a ge=
nuine<BR>inquiry, because there <BR>> might be an explanation I have not=
 thought of. <BR>> <BR>> I have one example where, via radio sweep, m=
y communicator was able<BR>to correctly <BR>> identify the status and lo=
cation of a missing person (who it turns<BR>out was alive and well, so <BR>=
> we ended up with confirmation that the info given had indeed been<BR>c=
orrect - which is <BR>> much less complicated that trying to track and u=
nderstand the clues<BR>when associated with <BR>> the dead, or missing b=
ut not found.) Again, if a hoax, would that<BR>have simply been a <BR>> =
lucky guess on the part of the hoaxer?<BR>> <BR>> Bottom line for me =
is ... have I wondered if it could be a hoax? Or<BR>simply a fortuitous <BR=
>> tuning of the dial? Yes, on both accounts. But there is enough<BR>com=
pelling evidence to rule <BR>> out both of them as an explanation for th=
e far too many relevant<BR>examples received by so <BR>> many of us.<BR>=
> <BR>> Good food for thought, but after digesting it, I'd have to sa=
y, "No,<BR>a sophisticated hoax <BR>> does not sufficiently explain the =
phenomena on a large scale."<BR>> <BR>> Margaret<BR>> <BR>> ---=
